dc:description:
DES was first reported in relation to semidominant Myofibrillar Myopathy in 1998 (Goldfarb et al. 1998, PMID: 9697706). Myofibrillar myopathy is a subset of inherited muscle diseases primarily characterized by progressive muscle weakness, atrophy, respiratory abnormalities, and cardiomyopathy. Over 100 variants, mostly missense and small in-frame indels, have been reported in human probands. Although this disorder largely segregates in an autosomal dominant manner, many confirmed cases of autosomal recessive probands have been characterized. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data, segregation data, and experimental data.
Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 11 probands in 7 publications (PMIDs; 17221859, 23687351, 19105189, 10717012, 9697706, 10545598, 11061256). Variants in this gene segregated with disease in 13 additional family members in 3 families. Significantly more evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic and experimental evidence has been reached. Although the primary mechanism for pathogenic DES variants is a gain-of-function causing desmin aggregates and clumping in the muscle fibers, there is evidence for some variants disrupting the desmin fiberous network or for a loss-of-function when multiple null variants are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner (PMIDs: 16217025, 31718026) This gene has historically been implicated in a form of recessive limb-girdle muscular dystrophy, but as of 2018 the association was reclassified as a type of myofibrillar myopathy (PMIDs: 23687351, 30055862).
This gene-disease association is additionally supported by many animal models, expression studies, and in vitro functional assays. There are several models that recapitulate either the entirety of phenotypes observed in human probands or a partial aspect, such as the skeletal myopathy or cardiomyopathy phenotypes. These models vary in the pathogenic mechanism, however they all provide strong evidence supporting the pathogenicity of DES null and other variants. DES is uniquely expressed in all types of muscle, further implicating this gene as related to the cardiac and skeletal myopathy phenotypes. A functional assay evaluating the effect of 14 different DES variants was conducted with all of them showing altered function, whether that be disrupting the proper assembly of sarcomeres and z-discs or forming aggregates that impairs the contration and relaxation of the muscle fibers.
In summary, DES is definitively associated with semidominant Myofibrillar Myopathy. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. 
This gene-disease-inheritance association was recurated according to ClinGen's recuration guidelines (last curation publication date 09/25/17, SOP Version 5).

evidence.dc:description: These two mouse models both recaptulate many of the skeletal myoapthy phenotypes observed in human probands, including muscle fiber alterations, weakness, desmin aggregates, and excess fibrosis/regeneration. Although this model does utilize a known pathogenic variant to model the disorder, the viral-mediated method does not yield an exact clinical picture when compared to a heterozygous knock-in model's inheritance and mechanism. Therefore, rather than the score being increased, this model recieves only default points.

Overexpression of WT desmin did not have any significant effect on muscle structure in observed control mice. In contrast, expression of both mutants in the mice muscle fibers yielded centrally nucleated muscle fibers, abnormal regeneration, and accumulations in the perinuclear regions. In the mouse WT muscle, desmin was correctly aligned like sarcomeres and showed no difference from untreated control muscles. However, expression of both mutants showed altered localization and accumulation around the nuclei and/or subsarcollemal regions. Both mutant lines showed significantly increased regeneration compared to the WT, demonstrating that the expression of this mutant desmin caused muscle fiber degredation. Perturbations and alterations of the z-line is also notable, since the sacromere disorganization is commonly observed in probands with muscular phenotypes such as weakness or atrophy. Reduced maximal active force production in the model was also noted, specifically with both R406W (-18.8%, P <0.001) and E413K (-18.1%, P <0.001) desmin-expressing muscles compared the the WT.
evidence.rdfs:label: DES Viral-Mediated Expression in Mice

evidence.dc:description: This DES null model shows how crucial desmin is for all muscle types, including the cardiac and skeletal muscle systems. Every phenotype observed in human myofibrillar myopathy probands are related to these organs, specifically the muscle weakness/atrophy and cardiomyopathy. Although this model does demonstrate all aspects of the human disorder, this more reflects the rarer loss-of-function pathogenic mechansim rather than the gain-of-function aggregates. However, since this model does recapitulate both types of phenotypes observed in the human probands, this model recieves a default score.

Desmin knockout mice (des_m1/m1) did not display any altered development or reproduction directly after birth. However, defects appeared in all three major muscle types (skeletal, smooth, cardiac) after birth in a progressive degeneration. The cardiac muscle showed many different phenotypes, specifically hypertrophy and dilated ventricles because of excessive cardiomyocyte degeneration. Skeletal muscle degeneration and weakness is also prevalent, with altered degeneration/necrosis casusing significant weakness and atrophy. Elevated Serum CK is observed as an indication of the degeneration, with ragged-red and internally nucleated fibers present in both human probands and the model. All of these degeneration patterns clearly show cardiac and skeletal weakness/atrophy and impairment, demonstrating that a key function for DES is maintainance of muscle tissue of all kinds in both mice and human probands.
evidence.rdfs:label: Null DES Mice Display Cardiac and Skeletal Abnormalities

evidence.dc:description: These variants all demonstrate altered function when expressed in cell lines compared to the wild-type. Specifically, they show a varying level of protein structure alterations that either cause disruption in the IF networks and/or cause protein aggregates that are unable to fulfill the proper function of the assembly. Because this large assay demonstrates that each of these 14 tested causative variants in DES have a similar impact on the protein structure and therefore on the function of the system, this evidence is increased to 1.0 points.

In-vitro assembly conditions were assessed for the WT and the 14 mutants. The WT desmin assembled into normal-looking filaments, however the 14 mutants all assembled into various alternate protein structures. DesA213V, DesE245D, DesA360P, DesQ389P, DesN393I, and DesD399Y all assembled into seemingly normal filaments though the actual function seems impaired via sticking and coalescing. Other mutant proteins also had various structural abnormalities such as disturbed annealing and radial compaction (DesL385P and DesR406W), enhanced filament adhesiveness and aggregate formation (DesA337P, DesN342D, and DesA357P), or conserved ULF formation with breakdown of assembly and assembly deterioration (DesL345P, DesR350P, and DesL370P). All of these mutants have alterations that would likely prevent the proper protein folding and function. Transfection into SW13 cells tested the function of other mutants to form proper IF networks, however they failed to assemble into proper structures in vitro.
evidence.rdfs:label: DES Mutants Assemble into Alternate Structures

evidence.dc:description: Desmin is responsible for proper z-disc assembly and sarcomere organization in all types of muscle. When the function is altered, the resulting accumulations can easily yield muscle weakness/atrophy and other related phenotypes. Therefore, this evidence earns default points.

Desmin is a crucial structural component of sarcomeric assembly. When variants in the DES gene result in a misfolded or otherwise defective protein, the mutants generally cause abnormal accumulations of proteins in the muscle fibers. These accumulations prevent normal function of the proteins and disrupt the normal sarcomeric organization and z-disc formation of the muscle. In all three types of muscle, this can yield muscle weakness/atrophy without the capability of properly contracting or relaxing.
evidence.rdfs:label: DES Function in Muscle

evidence.dc:description: Since this protein is uniquely expressed in muscle and all myofibrillar myopathy phenotypes are either cardiac or skeletal muscle related, this evidence earns default points.

Desmin and vimetin transcripts were located via RNA blot analysis. In all muscular systems, including striated, cardiac, and smooth muscle, one 2.2-kb transcript of DES was was detected. Cultured muscle cells had a much stronger signal, indicating that DES is actively synthesized in these types of cells. The Human Protein Atlas also supports these findings with an RNA tissue specification of "Tissue enhanced (heart muscle, skeletal muscle, smooth muscle)" and a protein expression type of "Selective cytoplasmic expression in heart, skeletal and smooth muscle".
evidence.rdfs:label: DES Uniquely Expressed in Muscle

evidence.dc:description: Although this proband has ample phenotypic evidence, the lack of variant-level evidence and pathogenic mechanisms for this variant yields a reduced 0.25 points.

evidence.rdfs:label: CEII-4
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Skeletal muscle strength: neck flexors 3, shoulder abductors 0, elbow flexors 1, elbow extensors 0, wrist extensors and flexors 0 (fixed), hip flexors 0, knee extensors 1, ankle dorsiflexors 0, ankle flexors 2 (0-5 scale); Serum CK at the age of 38 years was 123 U/L (n<191); The sarcolemmal expression of merosin, dystrophin, sarcoglycans (α, β, γ and δ) and dystroglycans (α and β) were normal on immunocytochemistry.

evidence.dc:description: A confirmed de novo variant plus ample phenotypic evidence and variant-level evidence (mutant desmin when expressed resulted in sacroplasmic aggregates and apoptosis with nuclear DNA condensation and fragmentation) yields an elevated 2.5 points.

evidence.rdfs:label: SU
evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was extracted from leukocytes or freeze-dried muscle of the proband, parents, and controls. Each DES exon in the patient and parents were amplified and directly sequenced. Total RNA was extracted and reverse transcription/PCR was performed and sequenced. Resstriction enzyme analysis confirmed the segregation pattern.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Serum CK of 1,276 IU/L (normal <215 IU/L); Left ventricular ejection fraction of 51% (normal, 50% to 80%); Widened Z discs were often observed and one-third of all sarcomeres was discontinued at the Z discs

evidence.dc:description: A confirmed de novo variant plus ample phenotypic evidence yields default points.

evidence.rdfs:label: DA6P
evidence.detectionMethod: Total RNA was isolated from muscle biopsy and reverse transcription was performed. PCR amplification and sequencing followed. Genomic DNA was also obtained from patients, their relatives, and controls via blood samples and PCR amplified/sequenced. Restriction enzyme analysis confirmed the variants in these probands and segregation.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Muscle biopsy was performed; Myofibrillar disruption, fragments of thin and thick filaments, streaming Z bands, and deposits of dense, amorphous material were prominent

evidence.dc:description: A confirmed de novo variant plus ample phenotypic evidence and variant-level evidence (PMID:21262226; mutant desmin when expressed was unable to form a filamentous network and yielded numerous dot-like aggregates in the cytoplasm) yields an elevated 2.5 points.

evidence.rdfs:label: DA5P
evidence.detectionMethod: Total RNA was isolated from muscle biopsy and reverse transcription was performed. PCR amplification and sequencing followed. Genomic DNA was also obtained from patients, their relatives, and controls via blood samples and PCR amplified/sequenced. Restriction enzyme analysis confirmed the variants in these probands and segregation.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Muscle biopsy was performed; Myofibrillar disruption, fragments of thin and thick filaments, streaming Z bands, and deposits of dense, amorphous material were prominent

evidence.dc:description: Not enough individuals
evidence.rdfs:label: CSM1

member.rdfs:label: CSM1P
member.detectionMethod: DES mutational analysis was performed by amplifying and sequencing all nine coding exons, identifying a heterozygous missense variant in all affected individuals.

evidence.dc:description: Not enough segregations
evidence.rdfs:label: DA3

member.rdfs:label: DA3P
member.previousTestingDescription: Normal Serum CK; Muscle biopsy was performed; Myofibrillar disruption, fragments of thin and thick filaments, streaming Z bands, and deposits of dense, amorphous material were prominent

evidence.dc:description: Not enough segregations
evidence.rdfs:label: DA4

member.rdfs:label: DA4P
member.previousTestingDescription: Serum CK at 364 U/l; Muscle biopsy was performed; Myofibrillar disruption, fragments of thin and thick filaments, streaming Z bands, and deposits of dense, amorphous material were prominent

evidence.dc:description: Enough segregations for evidence
evidence.rdfs:label: BA1

member.rdfs:label: BA1P
member.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was isolated from peripheral lymphocytes. DES, LMNA, and MYOT genes were all amplified and sequenced.
member.previousTestingDescription: Skeletal muscle biopsies and mutational screening were performed; Sequence analysis ruled out mutations in the aB-crystalline gene; Serum CK elevated 3-fold

evidence.dc:description: Not enough affected individuals
evidence.rdfs:label: CE

evidence.dc:description: Enough evidence
evidence.rdfs:label: SJ

member.rdfs:label: SJIV-2
member.detectionMethod: The DES region was sequenced in the index patient and V-24/V-25. All patients showed a heterozygous missense variant in the DES gene. Restriction enzyme analysis and SSCP analysis confirmed the presence and segregation of this variant with the disease.
member.previousTestingDescription: CK was mildly elevated, 350 IU/l (normal <150 IU/l); Electromyography: fibrillations and short duration, low amplitude, motor unit potentials, compatible with a myopathic process, were evident in multiple muscles of upper and lower extremities; ECG: first degree AV block, a right bundle branch block, ST segment elevations and inversion of T waves; Echocardiography: normal

evidence.dc:description: Enough individuals for evidence
evidence.rdfs:label: CL

member.rdfs:label: CLI-1
member.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was isolated from peripheral blood leukocytes and amplified via PCR for direct sequencing. RT-PCR was also performed to confirm the effects of the DES variant.
member.previousTestingDescription: Multiple fibers displayed dots of increased acid phosphatase reactivity within the cytoplasm and partially at the rim of larger vacuoles; Enzymatic stainings for myophosphorylase and phosphofructokinase were positive, and biochemical analysis of acid maltase activity in skeletal muscle gave normal results;

evidence.dc:description: Not enough segregations
evidence.rdfs:label: DA1

member.rdfs:label: DA1P
member.detectionMethod: Total RNA was isolated from muscle biopsy and reverse transcription was performed. PCR amplification and sequencing followed. Genomic DNA was also obtained from patients, their relatives, and controls via blood samples and PCR amplified/sequenced. Restriction enzyme analysis confirmed the variants in these probands and segregation.
member.previousTestingDescription: Muscle biopsy was performed; Myofibrillar disruption, fragments of thin and thick filaments, streaming Z bands, and deposits of dense, amorphous material were prominent; Father and two paternal uncles of the proband in Family 1 had initially been given a diagnosis of Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease before death in 40s/50s; Muscle biopsy was performed; Myofibrillar disruption, fragments of thin and thick filaments, streaming Z bands, and deposits of dense, amorphous material were prominent

evidence.dc:description: Not enough info

evidence.dc:description: Sufficent phenotypic evidence plus variant-level evidence (PMID:22403400 The N342D variant was expressed and cytoplasmic aggregates were detected independent of cell type; the samples also formed aggregates and small fibrils) gives this proband default points.

Sufficent phenotypic evidence is present, however there is limited variant-level evidence to support this variant's pathogenicity (preserved filamentous network organization in C2C12 cells although it does tend to interfere with localization/binding in vitro) and therefore is downscored to 0.1 points.

A splice-affecting variant with variant-level evidence (PMID:23615443; E245D showed significantly delayed dynamics compared to the wild-type, slowing remodeling in myocytes) yields an increased score of 1.0 points.

Sufficent phenotypic evidence plus variant-level evidence (When expressed in C2C12 cells and colocalized with WT Desmin, these variants revealed a disturbance of filament-formation competence and filament-filament interactions diminishing the biomechanical properties) gives this proband default points.

Sufficent phenotypic evidence plus variant-level evidence (PMID:16865695 The A337P variant was introduced into SW13 and C2C12 cells causing complete inability to form and produced multiple desmin-positive aggregates) gives this proband default points.
Curated in Dalakas et al
Sufficent phenotypic evidence plus variant-level evidence (Cells expressing the L345P variant show no filaments forming and do not incorporate into the IP network) yields default points.

Sufficent phenotypic evidence plus variant-level evidence (When expressed in C2C12 cells and colocalized with WT Desmin, these variants revealed a disturbance of filament-formation competence and filament-filament interactions diminishing the biomechanical properties) gives this proband default points.

evidence.rdfs:label: BA3P
evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was isolated from peripheral lymphocytes. DES, LMNA, and MYOT genes were all amplified and sequenced.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Skeletal muscle biopsies and mutational screening were performed; Sequence analysis ruled out mutations in the aB-crystalline gene; Serum CK of 335 IU/l

evidence.dc:description: This family has ample phenotypic evidence, however there is no variant-level evidence for these variants in a recessive manner. Therefore, this is downscored to 0.1 points.
